title: Arrow's Impossibility Theorem
formal_statement: No rank-order voting system can satisfy all of the following fairness criteria simultaneously when there are three or more alternatives: (1) Unrestricted domain, (2) Pareto efficiency, (3) Independence of irrelevant alternatives (IIA), (4) Non-dictatorship.
plain_language: There is no perfectly fair voting system for ranking three or more options that satisfies all intuitive fairness criteria. Every voting method must sacrifice at least one desirable property.
assumptions_scope: Three or more alternatives to choose from
All possible preference orderings allowed (unrestricted domain)
typical_traps: Claiming a perfectly fair rank-order voting system exists
Not recognizing that all voting methods violate at least one axiom
Assuming popular voting methods (plurality, ranked-choice) avoid the impossibility
Designing voting systems without analyzing which axioms are sacrificed

escape_hatches.description: Relax one of the fairness axioms
examples: Accept IIA violations (Ranked-choice voting, Borda count)
Restrict domain to single-peaked preferences (Median voter theorem)
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Specific fairness property violated; strategic voting opportunities may arise

escape_hatches.description: Use cardinal utilities instead of ordinal rankings
escape_hatches.trade_offs: Requires cardinal utility information (harder to elicit); strategic exaggeration possible
Limited applicability; agenda-setting power becomes critical; information loss

test_or_check: Identify if the claim involves rank-order aggregation with three or more alternatives. Check if all four Arrow axioms are claimed simultaneously. If yes, flag as conflicting with Arrow's theorem.
references: Arrow, K. J. (1950). A Difficulty in the Concept of Social Welfare. Journal of Political Economy, 58(4), 328-346. doi:10.1086/256963
Arrow, K. J. (1963). Social Choice and Individual Values (2nd ed.). Yale University Press.
notes: Arrow's theorem won the Nobel Prize in Economics and fundamentally changed how we understand democratic choice. It does not mean democracy is impossible, but that we must consciously choose which fairness criteria to prioritize.
